question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to scientifically evaluate function in biology, the philosophical origins of studying nature, and how philosophers establish goal-directedness.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about teleology, purpose, and philosophy in general.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about the history of the study of teleology from pre-Socratic times through the present. (Spoiler: McShea and Babcock are the present). I learned goal directedness is a sticky subject when applied to biology, and even scarier when applied to natural selection. We learned how defining function is important, and about free will and reductionism.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the lectures were fascinating. They provided a great opportunity for students to ask specific questions on the material we were reading for homework. McShea and Babcock are extremely knowledgable, so these lectures becoming Q&A was fascinating.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors did a great job of combining teaching with class discussions and this made the class environment very stimulating. Assigning readings before every class was helpful because it gave everyone time to read the primary sources and make their own assessments of them, then learn about what Babcock and McShea took away from them. Usually they don't align and you feel a little silly about your journal response. Journal responses are a good way to keep people honest about their readings. I'd keep the exam structure too for the most part.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. I've learnt, at least the foundations of seven different religions and traditions. They're all very interesting and offer valuable insight on how to approach different aspects of the good life.2. I've learnt to pick and choose more effectively. The seven different traditions and religions offer important lessons on different aspects of life. I agree with some, and disagree with others. For example, I appreciate the pragmatism of Stoicism (I think of myself as stoic to an extent), but some things to me are not indifferents, they're simply bad. I prefer Confucianism's focus on ritual in dealing with loss.3. I've learnt to appreciate writing more. We did a lot of writing in this class, particularly with the jounral entries and the many notes and questions we did in class. It's brought back a lesson I learnt from my old writing teaching: "writing is thinking". I've done a lot of thinking through writing in this class.

response_text: The class truly has the power to transform ideas. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand different points of view and relate with each other to find common ground in thought. In light of several issues concurrently happening around the world, this class was a breath of fresh air that allowed civil conversation organized by the amazing professors. The retreat also was placed at such a perfect time when I was studying for midterms, helping me escape the Duke bubble. Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. And this class reminded me of how important human interaction and conversation is.

response_text:

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having 8 different lecturers who were each so passionately involved with their respective traditions was genuinely so interesting and engaging every lecture. This method of changing topics every class made it easy to understand distinctions between units and ideas, and kept me invested in the course. I also really enjoyed having a journal and doing journal entries, as they were very personal and helped me reflect on my views in a very informal way. The dialogue group/dialogue performance was also great, as I got to build relationships with my classmates and produce something fun. The final reflective project and retreat were also great. Overall, having such dynamic meetings and assignments made the course really enjoyable.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the lack of communication and expectations between students and the professors has made the class a little less stimulating. The interest I and others would gain from lectures is often overshadowed by the confusion regarding deadlines and grading expectations. I know it is hard to coordinate a class with so many students and teachers, but sometimes assignment due dates feel rushed. I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

Transforming my worldview & my view of my undergraduate experience—what to prioritize, how to proceed with intentionality. —> Realizing the importance of slowing down & being present.The faculty are incredible. The readings were incredible & helped me reframe the way I thought about how I approached life. Guest speaker conversations (with dinner), especially the one focused on the Israel-Hamas War, really helped me ground reflection into the way I approached politics—it made me realize that religion can't really exist independently of politics, which changed the way I thought about political engagement.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The class was structured by unit and speakers took turns representing their own religion's commentary on those units. Every lecture was different and allowed to students to truly take something out of every time the class met. They also got the students involved through questions we submitted before class based on the readings, which encouraged even deeper discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the course material is insanely interesting. Like learning what buddhists think about success from an actual buddhist is awesome. The discussion sections were also fun if you do it with your friends

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked having professors come in and teach about their ideologies. Sometimes the readings didn't really relate to the unit, or I couldn't exactly pinpoint what that specific tradition was saying about the unit and how it related to the good life. Sometimes lectures were hard to follow. I did enjoy the panels and I really enjoyed the discussion groups because they were a good way of talking about our own ideas in relation to the good life.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really struggled with learning in this class and learning from it. The way that the class was structured made it really difficult to want to learn and I don't think that the different types of lecturers with all different types of teaching styles worked out well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course requires presence and full attention. I think that's not a ridiculous ask, as we were given journals to record our thoughts and take notes over the lectures. The journals were a key component of the learning experience, allowing us to disconnect from the internet.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Having the class split into categories for discussion helped cover all aspects of the religion or tradition we were studying. Transhumanism also being introduced as an official "tradition" was also very interesting to learn about considering the age we live in. The various professors engaged in amazing and important discussions that were interactive with questioning allowed at the end.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Had a lot of lecturers who were all extremely knowledge.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really liked when they did "debates" between two or more traditions, I think those were the most interesting classes because you got to directly compare what the traditions think on various topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I appreciated the discussions we had in class about different traditions, as it allowed for open conversations and learning from each perspective. I would like to continue having these discussions, similar to the panels, where we can actively engage with the class topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Lectures were taught by many different professors, which kept the class interesting! The retreat was definitely a highlight and unique Duke experience

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the lack of communication and expectations between students and the professors has made the class a little less stimulating. The interest I and others would gain from lectures is often overshadowed by the confusion regarding deadlines and grading expectations. I know it is hard to coordinate a class with so many students and teachers, but sometimes assignment due dates feel rushed. I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked how the course was organized and moved through different units pertaining to each religious tradition, this kept the course intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

I don't believe the discussions were as stimulating though because they were in such large groups. The days we were split into smaller groups within our discussion groups was when I  would actually meet and talk with people.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning more about major religions & traditions —> Thinking about my purpose here. Transforming my worldview & my view of my undergraduate experience—what to prioritize, how to proceed with intentionality. —> Realizing the importance of slowing down & being present.The faculty are incredible. The readings were incredible & helped me reframe the way I thought about how I approached life. Guest speaker conversations (with dinner), especially the one focused on the Israel-Hamas War, really helped me ground reflection into the way I approached politics—it made me realize that religion can't really exist independently of politics, which changed the way I thought about political engagement.

response_text: The Transformative Ideas program is amazing, but you would probably find more fulfillment in one of their smaller courses. The retreat is awesome and was one of the highlights of my sophomore year.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned different approaches to seeing ethical problems, ways to think about living life ethically, and the basics of constructing an ethical/philosophical argument.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class has taught me how to identify and construct solid arguments, identify ethics in our everyday lives, and draw relation to foundational ethical inquiries to modern-day problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think i learned how to evaluate ethical issues and arguments, I learned how to draft ethical arguments

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I really liked the discussions in this class as it was super nice to have a variety of opinions being expressed. I learned about Existentialism, Consequentialism, and an overall framework for evaluating ethical issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: New methods to tackle ethical dilemmas, insights into different ethical frameworks, reflection about how to live life

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to create an ethical argument, debate ethical arguments, and think critically about my own life and what things I do in it and what should or should not be done based on ethics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a lot of knowledge about how to think about living morally. I now know what questions to ask myself when I find myself in an ethical dilemma. I also gained insight into what living a good life might entail, and that that question is much more philosophical than it may seem at first.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to approach answering/trying to answer ethical questions, different ways of thinking about ethics (e.g. utilitarianism, consequentialism, etc.), and developing arguments to attack/defend ethical positions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to make ethical observations and become more in tune with my own morality. I have become more well-versed in philosophical texts. I learned about different philosophers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to approach ethical issues by deconstructing arguments. We also approached them through open discussions as opposed to a rigid system of reading and reviewing different ethics papers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Making ethical inquiries daily and considering the pros and cons of thinking a certain way in an ethical context. Knowing how to back up your arguments for a certain type of ethics academically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel like I learned how to make a concrete argument in this class. We practiced this most classes by making arguments about ethical questions. I learned how to work towards an ethical conclusion through an argument in this class. Other than this, I learned how to apply what I learned in class to my own life. In other words, my thought process for what I should or shouldn't do has been affected by this class and it has taught me how to make decisions. The way I think has been altered by the topics we've talked about in this class, for example how many spoons you can take from Trinity Cafe. I never would have thought about this before this class, but I feel it has made me a better person. Another thing I learned in this class is how to prioritize different things in my life. Through all of the readings and discussions in class a major theme was what to prioritize. I feel that after all of this, my understanding of the priorities in my life has been made a lot better. You can only focus on so much, so you have to focus on what has meaning to you, which is what I learned through this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The environment is very discussion-heavy. There are weekly (ish) written assignments where we are asked to reflect on our own lives, and then in class we discuss readings with a small group and with the class. I liked the written assignments because they were low-stakes, but encouraged me to think critically about my own life and to connect themes from class. The class is also relatively stress-free, and Dr. Summers emphasizes the importance of discussions over worrying about grades.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

I would keep this kind of instruction, and also all of the articles from that specific website were much more digestible and interesting.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The way we were given the opportunity to think and come up with thought-provoking answers instead of feeling pressure to just answer immedaitely was a great way of learning how to answer philosophical questions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the dominant and foundational stances on philosophy of science, the mind, and religion from Descartes to Gould to Chalmers. I learned the specific structures of arguments like that of Descartes' epistemology, Plantinga's rebuttal to naturalistic evolution, and Jackson's qualia argument against reductive physicalism. I was given the space to show my understanding of these stances and practice synthesizing my thoughts on the matter.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course is one of my favorite classes that I've taken at Duke. It gave me so much insight into how to think about things like science, neuroscience, biology from not only a scientific perspective but also a perspective that is focused on questioning the nature of these things. I'm a computer science major and never really got exposure to natural sciences as a whole and this class was a perfect way to be able to get that exposure. It was amazing to be able to touch on so many things such as physics, biology, computer science even from a perspective of philosophical inquiry and relating it to religion. It really gave me the skills and tools to be able to question my own views not only about science but about everything I do and really get to the bottom of whatever I'm learning or thinking about.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Deconstructing complex philosophical/biological/physical arguments into palatable simple ones. I was really forced to understand the concepts underlying some of the most important questions that we as humans face, such as the reliability of our cognitive faculties. The essay prompts broke down these concepts and I'm definitely going to be breaking down complicated concepts in a similar way that the professor did for future difficult essays. 
2. Understanding of neuroscience -- I'm not a neuroscience major and so I had no prior knowledge on how the brain worked at all. Getting to hold a human brain in my own hands was really special and I thought that the level of information that we could get was varied enough that a neuroscience major would learn something and a newbie like me could as well. 
3. One of my biggest insights into the class was being truly captivated by my fellow Duke peers' intellect. Many of us came from different majors and backgrounds and every person added such an interest take to the conversations. I was truly impressed with the depth of knowledge and philosophical thinking of my peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first ever philosophy class, and I would highly recommend it for anybody wanting to explore the subject. I learned how to think very deeply about some of the biggest questions, write detailed papers on philosophical arguments, and perhaps most importantly, how to ask questions and work towards the answer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Wow, this class was so much better than I anticipated. I truly enjoyed learning about the intersections between science and religion, in a way that held space for all opinions, faiths, and backgrounds. I didn't feel like one faith or perspective was pressed onto us, and I learned how to dive into my thoughts and mind and truly decide where I stood on issues. I learned how complex conversations surrounding evolution truly are through the different evolutionary theories-- I did not realize how much of evolutionary theory was not agreed upon, because in high school it seemed like Darwinian- natural selection was the main and agreed upon definition of evolution. Also, I have never taken a philosophy class before, and I am so glad I took this one, because I learned about various ancient philosophers, how to contrast their ideas, and specifically learned about their ideas of the mind and God, which I find fascinating as a Neuroscience student. Finally, we went to Prof. Len White's brain lab, and I had so much fun going in the context of this course. Looking at the biological brain, but harboring these deep questions about religion and what it means to be human in the back of my mind from our readings, was truly remarkable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Critical Analysis of Interdisciplinary Themes: I developed the ability to critically evaluate how neuroscience and religion intersect, particularly in understanding the neurological basis of spiritual experiences and how these are perceived in various cultural contexts.
2. Integrative Thinking: This course emphasized synthesizing diverse perspectives from scientific literature, philosophical texts, and theological frameworks to address complex questions about the human condition.
3. Effective Argumentation: I learned to craft arguments that bridge empirical evidence with abstract reasoning, enabling thoughtful discourse on topics that often evoke polarizing views, as exhibited during class seminar and long papers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
QUESTION ONE:
1. Engaging Lectures: Both the instructor's dynamic lectures and his incorporation of incredible guest lectures combined clear explanations of scientific concepts with thought-provoking questions that encouraged deeper exploration, in a non-conventional lecture format.
Discussion-Based Learning: The emphasis on open discussion allowed students to express diverse viewpoints and refine their arguments collaboratively. After each comment, the instructor maintained the ideal balance between validating his students' beliefs, further fostering an environment in which communication is valid, and also challenging them, asking follow-up questions intended with gauging their depth of analysis.
QUESTION TWO (Components to Retain):
1. Interdisciplinary Readings: Including a blend of neuroscience papers, religious texts, and philosophical essays was invaluable for a holistic learning experience. I will most definitely be re-reading my favorites of the one's he provided, like Lucretius and Plantinga. Not a single reading was short of exceedingly awe-provoking.
Interactive Class Discussions: These fostered a sense of intellectual curiosity among students, compelling me to take the class' complex commentary on the workings of the world with me everywhere I go as I continue to grapple with pressing inquiries, like the pursuit for meaning and the epistemological explanation for existence.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The conflict between ideological loyalty and material harm prevention—whether in the regulation of AI-generated disinformation or in the defense of capitalist market structures—reveal the same pattern repeats: ideology-first positions prioritize abstract principles even when faced with clear evidence of harm, while material-first positions seek to address concrete damage, even at the cost of ideological purity. This essay will show how this underlying dynamic shapes both debates over AI regulation and the longstanding capitalism versus communism controversy.In the current debates surrounding AI regulation, especially around deepfake imagery and disinformation, the divide is sharp. Anti-regulation advocates adopt an ideology-first stance, prioritizing principles of free speech absolutism and market autonomy. Organizations like the Cato Institute frame any attempt to regulate AI content as a slippery slope to censorship or dangerous government overreach. Similarly, the narrative that "innovation must be free from interference" dismisses the material harms caused by AI disinformation — such as manipulated election outcomes, voter suppression, and the erosion of public trust. The underlying ideological commitment to liberty and free market operation remains firm even in the face of mounting evidence that AI technologies, left unchecked, can profoundly destabilize democratic institutions.Conversely, pro-regulation advocates adopt a material-first position, focusing not on preserving ideological purity, but on minimizing measurable harm. They prioritize policies like mandatory watermarking of AI-generated media, platform accountability for disinformation campaigns, and transparency requirements for algorithmic content distribution. Their arguments are grounded in concrete evidence: AI models have exacerbated biases in hiring, deepened misinformation flows, and enabled new forms of exploitation and surveillance. Rather than focusing on deontological arguments about abstract rights, material-first proponents insist that preventing real-world damage must take precedence, even if it entails some limitations on absolute free expression or market freedom.This structure mirrors the capitalism versus communism debate throughout the twentieth century. Capitalist apologetics frequently operated from an ideology-first perspective, framing free markets and competition as "natural" forces immune to political critique. Ideologies of meritocracy — that wealth and success reflect personal virtue — mystified systemic inequalities, obscuring the exploitation and structural violence embedded in global capitalism. Even as ecological collapse, labor precarity, and extreme wealth gaps became more visible, defenders of market ideology dismissed these harms as "externalities" rather than evidence of fundamental flaws. Their loyalty remained not to empirical outcomes but to the abstract sanctity of market competition.On the other side, critiques of capitalism — including socialist and communist thought — adopt a material-first approach. These critiques prioritize harm reduction: alleviating poverty, protecting ecological systems, ensuring workers' rights, and reducing systemic inequality. They are less concerned with preserving the ideological purity of economic "freedom" and more concerned with minimizing the tangible suffering produced by capitalist systems. Whether through labor protections, wealth redistribution, or environmental regulation, material-first critiques demand that abstract ideals yield when faced with material devastation.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In the traditional model of ideological control, elites dominate mental production by distributing first-order ideological content: direct messages about what is true, good, or desirable. However, this is no longer the only — or even the primary — mechanism. In the contemporary world, not only does mental production distribute first-order ideology, but also the enforcement of second-order ideology additionally distributes first-order ideology. Seemingly neutral frameworks like "free speech," "anti-misinformation," and "anti-hate speech" are second-order ideologies that not only prescribe how the media should distribute first-order content but universalize first-order values through their enforcement. Thus, the public inherits first-order ideologies not only from the media itself but derive them from universal prescriptions of what kinds of communication are deemed legitimate.Consider "misinformation" enforcement. During the Cold War, elites not only flooded the media with anti-communist messages; they also framed sympathy toward communism itself as "misinformation" or "subversion." Thus, communism being bad was not only simply conveyed through the arguments the media made, but through ruling the discussion of alternatives as inherently illegitimate and a form of misinformation. In this context, "misinformation" as a second-order ideology was a direct extension of a first-order ideological battle: capitalism versus communism.In today's technocratic context, however, "misinformation" serves a different second-order function. The contemporary enforcement of "misinformation" on the surface seems to be a simple second-order filter for accuracy. However, such a filter spreads a universalist belief in objective truth — the idea that there exists a singular, recognizable reality that must be protected and disseminated for the sake of social cohesion and progress. Through this enforcement, public life becomes organized around a metaphysics of universal objectivity, where being properly informed is valued above all else.The antithesis of this is free speech absolutism. Media and education have long glorified individual liberty, often portraying censorship as synonymous with tyranny. The enforcement of free speech absolutism — treating any regulation of speech as dangerous — quietly installs this ideological lesson as a universal framework: that freedom is valued above all else, even at the expense of others' feelings, social cohesion, or truth itself. In this framework, we value our freedom over information integrity, emotional safety, and democratic stability, perpetuating the first-order libertarian ideal without openly stating it.Similarly, anti-hate speech policies reveal how second-order frameworks distribute first-order ideology. Modern pluralistic societies emphasize the protection of marginalized groups, and content celebrating diversity and inclusion is everywhere. The enforcement of "anti-hate" regulations carries this deep implication: that emotional harm and subjective feelings deserve institutional protection. Thus, anti-hate enforcement teaches that our feelings should be valued — that emotional safety is not merely a private concern, but a political and communicative standard that reshapes the public sphere.In each case, second-order enforcement distributes first-order ideology by naturalizing its assumptions about legitimacy, safety, harm, and truth. What appears as neutral procedural management — combating misinformation, protecting speech, ensuring emotional safety — is in fact the continuation of elite interests by other means. Thus, mental production is no longer simply about distributing beliefs; it is about embedding frameworks that structure the conditions of belief themselves. Today's ideological domination operates not only on the level of what we think, but even more profoundly on what kind of relationship to truth, harm, and freedom we are allowed to have.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Wow. Learned a lot. We started with a pretty fundamental overview of the history behind the philosophy of mind. We started with Descartes, the father of modern philosophy, and moved on from there. Our book, Minds and Computers, concluded with computational theory of mind, which argues that if humans are machines, the brain is basically the hardware and the mind is the software. However, Searle showed us that computationalism can't answer intentionality (formal programs can't constitute understanding), so we have tried to find other theories that may work to explain the mind. Between Heidegger, Wittgenstein, Brentano, Dennet, Hagel, we have come to realize the importance of subjective experience in the world. So far, I really like the embodied mind theory and its appeal to naturalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a knowledge of eras, how those eras and the events during shaped the thoughts of philosophers during those times, and how those philosophers built thoughts on previous thoughts. And all of this knowledge was achieved through reading prominent, classic literature that we were able to learn how to interpret and interact with in order to gain philosophical insights from them. It was very interesting how each philosopher's circumstances drove their thinking, and how that thinking was able to be built upon and developed over time throughout many more eras and philosophers. And it was all about arguably the most important question one can ask themselves: what is the meaning of life? I was able to learn more about philosophers who thought there is an inherent meaning to life and what that meaning looked like to them, that there is not meaning to life, or that certain factors/experiences/mindsets could give one meaning.

response_text: I would say that the content is very interesting and that you learn, what I think, is an essential way of thinking in life. I think that this class helped me immensely with this. The class is a lot of reading as you read a book a week, but all for good reason. If you can manage the amount reading and can spend time on it, it will allow you to make more out of the class and be able to make more connections and develop your own ideas. The grading is pretty vague, but seems to be mostly participation based along with three papers throughout the semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Became intimately familiar with philosophies of Simone Weil, Simone de Beauvoir, and Iris Murdoch through close readings. Learned ethics in a way that was immediately applicable to everyday life. Gained insights about the influence of these thinkers on one another, particularly Simone Weil of whom I had close to no knowledge of before entering the course. One of my favorite things was when Professor Moi filled in historical/philosophical context around these thinkers (wartime, surrounding literature, Wittgenstein, Hegel, etc)--made it feel less like narrowing in on these random philosophers in a vacuum.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Smaller readings allowed me to pay closer attention to each text and get more out of subsequent lectures and discussions. I liked the attention journals as a way to keep me closely engaged with the texts throughout the week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought that in terms of content, the course flowed quite nicely. I thought beginning with Weil and ending with Murdoch (from our big three names) was the ideal order, with Weil's concept of attention framing the whole course and Murdoch's vision-based moral theory bringing together attention and action, as well as offering a more realistic and individualized moral approach (compared to Weil's saintly expectations and Beauvoir's more politically-grounded perspective).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: some parts I just didn't understand or so much reading was given over a weekend and i have so many other things to do for my other classes that i wasn't able to do it (e.g. a whole novel was given over a weekend)

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very stimulating because of the ties to other fields of thought and in-depth analysis.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I have not delved deeply into either of these three thinkers in my prior classes and being able to engage deeply with the three thinkers made this class stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings are extremely complex and challenging, so it was certainly a class where you would always have to think deeply in relation to every component of the course: writing, asking questions, making presentations, and reading.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings are all very enlightening. I think the class was stimulating because of how it connects three philosophers together and shows a connecting thread among very different ideas.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I feel like adding more literature would make the class more stimulating and would make it so that the philosophy actually has to be dealt with and applied to examples. With the purpose of paying attention,  I think there is also a lot more room for poetry!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussions and slack channels!!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Clearer delineation of the relationship between Beauvoir and the other two

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course texts and class discussion were both very interesting and illuminating on the moral theories of these three women and the ways in which that could apply to any individual's ordinary life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: i definitely recommend! great professor and the other students who take this course were amazing. it is sometimes difficult to grasp if you've never read philosophy before but still do-able

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this course, meet with the professor in office hours, and be ready to devote time to thinking about the readings in order to fully understand their concepts.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is challenging but fruitful - you will learn a new way of thinking about Weil, Beauvoir, and Murdoch. Professor Moi is clearly an expert in her field and takes teaching very seriously. I felt that she was able to open up the readings we did in class in a way that helped me grasp the main ideas more easily.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's certainly a challenging course, and can feel a bit intimidating at times, but it also is extremely rewarding in that you'll end the semester with a thorough understanding of several important and relevant philosophical ideas.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course will give you a good understanding of various philosophers that are not often taught in the philosophy department. Learning about Weil has really expanded my view of the world. I see her influence everywhere and am so glad I learned about her in particular.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Strongly recommend. These philosophers we learned in this class, inter alia, were wonderful and provided a different vision in terms of our daily dealing with others.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you are open to this kind of influence, this class will affect the way you move in the world and your relationships. There were times I didn't necessarily feel very intellectually stimulated, but then would find myself considering concepts from class in non-class situations.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would definitely recommend this course, or any course taught by Professor Moi! Though her classes are challenging, she is an absolutely wonderful professor, and the works she teaches will transform the way you think about your own life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reading difficult complex philosophy, thinking about the relation between literature and philosophy, and articulating thoughts and writing thoughts about complex philosophy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this course, I learned how to analyze philosophical texts and thin deeply about the concepts they cover. I also learned how to write essays that further my understanding of philosophy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Reading skill. I read many excellent readings with the professor and my classmates.

3. Presentation skill.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about Weil, Beauvior and Murdoch, three female philosphers and their worldviews. I learned how to write more philosphical paper as well as really think philosphically

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The course definitely improved my ability to write both through the activity of writing (blog posts, the first essay), but moreso through an engagement with writers in an active manner that helped to inculcate what effective writing looks like and feels like. Most importantly, the course helped to teach me the importance of attention throughout my life, and to equip me with different tools for the training and use of attention.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Each reading we were assigned was very deliberate in advancing a specific philosophical concept, which I enjoyed. I also appreciated how they were all manageable in length/content such that it was actually feasible to read everything before the next class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the lecture, and the weekly reading posts. It was a perfect mix of discussion and lecturing. Honestly for these types of classes with very thorough dense philosophy, I prefer lecture more which this class leaned towards a bit more.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really loved our discussions in this course, they really solidified my understanding. I also think the blog posts were a good way to analyze the texts more deeply.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Close reading.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think the readings that we did and the lectures in class really complemented each other. I really enjoyed the blog posting aspect as well as it gave me a really great opportunity to think, because writing is thinking

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that both class discussion and the blog postings were effective. Some of the moments of the course which helped me understand the texts the most were engagements with the texts on the clas blog, both through my own postings as well as through the exploration of my classmate's ideas on the topics.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I really liked the connections between the philosophy and literature and found I was really able to connect with the main ideas of each of the thinkers and take in what they say as a part of my own world view.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Good in depth exploration and explanation of the thinkers discussed. The selected writings were very well selected and in concert with one another so that each week's reading felt like it effectively constructed my knowledge.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class if you are interesting in philosophy, literature, theory or anything related at all. Note that this is not a feminist philosophy class, more so a class about women philosophers. I think these are philosophers that are underrated in the academic canon, although Beauvoir is quite popular now. But definitely Simone Weil is an underrated writer and philosopher that everyone should read. Professor Moi is also a great teacher who understands students and the texts quite well. The amount of texts you read in this class is perfect. Long enough that you get a deep enough understanding of the philosopher, but also not too long so that it becomes unmanageable. The texts are also enlightening and perfectly difficult to understand so when you do get some insight it feels nice and illuminating.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: prepare to read and start your essays ealry!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Readings are not easy but interesting

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: As with most reading based humanities courses, you get in what you put out. I think you should take to heart the teachings of the writers, paying attention, opening yourself up, awknowledgement to really get a complete engagement with everything we learn about

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You should! Its one of the best philosophy and one of the best literature classes I've taken at Duke, and it has spillover not just to the everyday but to the everyday within the University which is helpful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to think and read about what Wittgenstein is doing in Philosophical Investigation. 
2. The context of philosophy of language which Wittgenstein is responding to and that which he himself spurs 
3. Relationship between and stakes of skepticism, knowledge/acknowledgement, literature, and morality as they invoked in ordinary language philosophy

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned to see language in a different way.
I learned about Wittgenstein's later philosophy.
I learned how to do philosophy as an expression of my self.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A ground-level understanding of Wittgenstein, including terminology like "grammar" and "criteria"; what it means to conduct a Wittgensteinian investigation; some of the consequences of Wittgenstein's diagnoses for philosophy and literary theory more broadly

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I like the blog posts assignment because I felt the instructor was earnestly asking us to write about what confused us. I appreciated her replies to these posts. I also thought class discussion and the knowledge and context which the instructor provided were very good. I appreciated the instructor's transparency and genuineness in her answers to questions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The seminar was great. One of the best classes I've had at Duke. Prof does a great job of leading seminars, leading people to the right directions and not straying too far from topic.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moi really has a great style of teaching. It has been a great journey that she guided us through Wittgenstein's work. I think we first-time learners of Wittgenstein all somewhat have a tendency to fall into the trap of abstraction and over-philosophicalization, and Wittgensteinian spirit is really all about get outside such a picture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The blog posts and required responses were very helpful; the relatively slow pace of the readings was also very conducive to actual understanding of the material

response_text: The content, especially the readings

response_text: I'd recommend it. I think it provides a way of thinking which is otherwise and often missing from other classes and intellectual discussions on the topic of language.

response_text: Must take.

response_text: If you are interested in ordinary language philosophy or Wittgenstein, take this class!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered a wide variety of topics in the fields of ethics and neuroscience. I learned about fundamental moral theories and how contemporary neuroscience research informs and complicates our understanding of agency, the penal system, and more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned different theories of how emotion and reason contribute to ethical decision-making, I learned a lot about psychopathy, and I learned about the distinction between the ethics of neuroscience and the neuroscience of ethics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about various brain structures and how they relate to specific functions. I learned about how neuroscience and law interact. I learned about how consciousness is perceived and analyzed from a neuroscientifc lens.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: ethical discussions and talking with others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about the neurobiological bases of psychopathy, moral judgments, and addiction.

response_text: How to think philosophically and hold philosophical discourse, how to integrate multidisciplinary information, how to be scientifically literate, and how to critically analyze scientific studies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

In his class, I learned how to best form an argument, how to think constructively about others' arguments, and perhaps most importantly, I developed a new way of understanding the world around me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

There exist ideas and concepts that can not be reduced from its current state or who’s origin can not be expressed in human language.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

We learned how to make different philosophical arguments, learned a great deal about various famous philosophers and their work, and learned to challenge traditional viewpoints.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to properly read high level text, how to break apart arguments (deductive and inductive) by looking at each of their parts, and how to write essays well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Throughout this course I have learned how to logically read philosophy essays in order to determine what the writer is trying to say. The biggest advice I feel that the professor gave me was that philosophy is like a math logic problem, but in writing. This course has been focused on what makes a sound argument theism, the difference between deduction and induction, the mind vs. brain, the applications of AI and free will. I have learned to not take anything at face value, rather it is important to make sure every part of an argument is sound.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned to separate inductive and deductive reasoning, and came to understand the best uses of each type of argument.
2. I developed philosophical foundations for my everyday views including topics such as God, the body and mind, and free will.
3. I learned to construct organic philosophical arguments from an array of viewpoints.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned about famous philosophers like Rowe, Paley, Swinburne, and Mackie and their contributions to our current understandings of the universe.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Philosophy is inherently a difficult subject, but because Professor Rosenberg had us complete the assigned readings before class and then later discuss them, I had a way to strengthen my understanding and make sure I knew what was going on. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This is probably the most well taught course I've ever taken in my life, and I wouldn't be surprised if it remains so. Professor Rosenberg lectures in a way that is informative and focused but also conversational. Lectures stay focused on topic and provide deep rich detail in a clear manner, and successfully avoids wasting time on poor explanations or repeating information. Lectures are highly informative and imaginative and engaging thanks to Rosenberg, but he also keeps them conversational where anyone can raise their hand with an objection or question that he will address perfectly. All classes and all information should be taught like this.Essays and weekly assignments are also done extremely well. Optional attendance is also an extremely positive factor.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The beauty of philosophy, or at least as Professor Rosenberg presented it, is that it opens up a whole new way of understanding the world around you.  I never would have considered whether the mind is different from the brain, if computers can think, or if humans have free will.  The class itself was intellectually stimulating, and its open discussion format allowed for students to be further intellectually stimulated by being able to discuss with Professor Rosenberg his ideas.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: In this course, you will be diving deep into some of the most significant problems in philosophy and looking at several arguments for each topic in detail. Definitely take this course if you are interested in thinking deeply about philosophical questions, but don't expect to necessarily leave the class with conclusive answers to any of the questions discussed.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend this course to students interested in expanding their knowledge of philosophy who don't mind a few short writing assignments. I would highly recommend meeting with Professor Rosenberg or the TA if you have any questions regarding the material or what to write for an essay.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

You will also read and analyze philosophical papers and learn the difference between deductive vs. inductive arguments, and what makes a good argument.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is an excellent introduction to philosophy, offering a well-rounded exploration of foundational topics like ethics, metaphysics, and epistemology. Be prepared to engage deeply with challenging texts and develop your critical thinking skills. Professor Rosenberg is incredibly knowledgeable and brings enthusiasm to every lecture. Discussion sections and office hours are invaluable, so take advantage of them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take if interested in philosophy and/or science.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I took away a new amount of knowledge when it comes to philosophy. I didn’t know much about approving the topic before, but I feel like a have a better understanding of philosophy and many of the topics that come with it. I learned 1) philosophical principles and concepts, 2) different authors and what their stances are on a certain topic, and 3) how to go about forming premises and understanding philosophical issues in a text or essay.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: One thing I learned was how to read philosophic papers. We had a specific way that we would read through each paper in order to get what we wanted out of it. Another thing I learned was how to work in a group to discuss opinions and other stuff. A third thing that I learned was how to effectively write a response essay to philosophic paper.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the basic forms of formal logic, a variety of philosophies and philosophers, and how to construct and assess an argument. Critical thinking skills generally were developed from this course, in a way it was defend what you believe or reason our why you believe it and is it reasonable which is a good skill to have in life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

engagement with readings to learn the key insights from a text
