a philosophical lens to view the World

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class, I learned many valuable skills that were surprisingly interdisciplinary. One skill I learned was reading and understanding philosophy papers, which helped me in other classes where I had to do difficult readings. I learned how to take good notes and extract the central argument that the philosophers we read were trying to make. Another topic I learned about in this course for the first time was the principles of logic and the importance of those principles in constructing a good argument. I felt that learning about logic has made me a better arguer and writer overall, and I feel like I use those skills in my everyday life. A third way of thinking that I learned in this class was how to argue and disagree with others using robust arguments. I learned about the importance of having good objections and not straw manning peoples arguments.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the skills to better able analyze and critique arguments, and even though the arguments we focused on in class were philosophical I feel like I going forward I can use a lot of what I learned here in regards to other subjects. Likewise, I think that just learning the basics of many types of philosophies (specifically arguments about human nature and Kant's deontology) has helped me engage more thoughtfully with subject matter in my other classes. Last, I think that because we had so many quizzes and a somewhat unpredictable timing of them it made me a better close-reader and also learn how to better approach tests/change my mindset around test taking.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to read philosophical literature. I learned how to deconstruct an argument by its validity. And I would say that I learned to look at thinks through more of a philosophical lens.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze old texts and find out the main idea from all of the writing. I learned how to have good discussions with my classmates. I learned how to read philosophy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to construct a logical argument. 
I learned how to read and digest philosophical literature. 
I learned a breadth of moral and prudential ethical theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to critically engage with philosophical text from philosophers such as Xunzi, Rawls, Kant, and Mill, breaking down their arguments into understandable pieces in and outside of class. I learned how to evaluate arguments using logic to assess the soundness of the author's premises or the overall validity of the argument. Moreover, I was able to implement the aforementioned methods to reconstruct and coherently reject a philosopher's argument in my final essay.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned the basics of logic and how philosophers make their arguments. I also learned how to think more about my arguments and how to try and construct steel-man arguments. Additionally, I learned how to accept and reckon with ideas that made sense in my head, but didn't sit right with me emotionally.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I felt like the classroom was always a very open place to discuss, and I felt like both of the instructors did a good job of facilitating open group discussions whenever possible. I also never felt nervous to ask questions, and I felt like the classroom was always a place where I could be curious. I liked the little case studies that we would start each class with as a way to get the discussion going. I felt like they were fun and thought-provoking. I also felt like the amount of work for the class was very reasonable, not too much, and not too little. Additionally I felt like the slides were always helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

response_text:
The instructor often separated us into small groups to dissect specific parts of readings and had us present back to the class. I think that working with other people this way was helpful to break down some of the readings that had difficult or dense language, and it also prompted sharing of different viewpoints. 
 
I also think the short writing assignments should be kept, as they prompt the student to think about the readings beyond what was discussed in class and come up with their own ideas. 
At the end the instructor allowed us to pick two "choice" awards, which I liked and I think this component should be kept. I would also keep the debate, as it both forced you to look deeper into the material and also develop logic and argument skills at the same time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: For one, we were a very small class of 7, in a room that had a large oval table that made us have to look at one another. This is the smallest class I have taken at Duke, and I was a little nervous that classes might contain a lot of awkward silences. Although there were a few of them, Ms.Duke made sure to engage the class with different questions, and would make sure to rephrase the question if there was any small confusion. She would often cold-call to make sure people understood where we were within our readings, and even if the student did not completely understand, would make sure to assist the student in finding a section within our readings that would help the student understand it better. Overall, Ms.Duke acted as a facilitator to our learning, making sure to provide more than enough time to answer questions and discuss more complex topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel like I learned how to make a concrete argument in this class. We practiced this most classes by making arguments about ethical questions. I learned how to work towards an ethical conclusion through an argument in this class. Other than this, I learned how to apply what I learned in class to my own life. In other words, my thought process for what I should or shouldn't do has been affected by this class and it has taught me how to make decisions. The way I think has been altered by the topics we've talked about in this class, for example how many spoons you can take from Trinity Cafe. I never would have thought about this before this class, but I feel it has made me a better person. Another thing I learned in this class is how to prioritize different things in my life. Through all of the readings and discussions in class a major theme was what to prioritize. I feel that after all of this, my understanding of the priorities in my life has been made a lot better. You can only focus on so much, so you have to focus on what has meaning to you, which is what I learned through this class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The environment is very discussion-heavy. The class is also relatively stress-free, and Dr. Summers emphasizes the importance of discussions over worrying about grades.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

The way we were given the opportunity to think and come up with thought-provoking answers instead of feeling pressure to just answer immedaitely was a great way of learning how to answer philosophical questions.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

He truly cares about his students, and he tries to prioritize the students' personal reflection and growth over the actual grading system to the best of his ability, which I think adds to the class's environment.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: PHIL 150 is a logic course which teaches the underlying concepts used in a multitude of forums.  Key components learned as follows:1)  A basic understanding of the systems of Quantified and Sentenial logic as well as the application of mathematical concepts to the basic terms used.2) Development of truth tables to substantiate validity, consistency and logical equivalence of statements in English as well as translated in mathematical variables3) Developing proofs for the above concepts including the use of basic mathematical/logical steps and derived rules for the exchange or logic statements

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's not a philosophy class. Though there's literally no math at all, its basically a math class. Like imagine just learning algebra again, or even a very very low level coding course.My one tip is to be okay with taking things for granted/as a given. You won't fully understand why we're doing something, but its not necessary to at all to do well. We're trying to translate english into a "math" per se, but english is obviously a language that isn't "consistent" for lack of a better word, so you don't realize what you're really saying when you say something. (e.g. "If you cut the red wire, then the bomb will explode" is not the same as "The bomb will explode only if you cut the red wire". The first means "If R, then B" and the second means "If B, then R"). You'll learn why that is, which will be weird and very abstract, but there's no reason to care or remember why that is. You just need to remember "B only if R" means "If B then R' and take that for granted/memorize it.Once you accept that, the class gets very easy.

I developed a more systematic yet scholar method to engage in philosophical discourse.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is awesome, and professor Janiak is a must have instructor. This course is suitable as an introduction if you've never taken philosophy before and assumes no prior knowledge. Skills: how to read and write philosophy (Janiak's 7 maxims), how to cleanly write out arguments. 
Knowledge: The dominant metaphysical and epistemic ideas of the modern era. Topics include motion, space, time, causation (whether it exists), causal principles like the PSR, free will, the difference between reality and how to represent reality (i.e. our idea of reality), dualism, skepticism and others.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely learned how to think more abstractly. This course requires you to sometimes step outside of yourself and your views to consider views that you might not have ever considered or might not agree with, so I was constantly challenging my own perspective and coming to new ways of thinking about social and political life. I also improved my speaking and writing skills through this course. By requiring us to write about what we read and by requiring participation, I was explaining some of these abstract concepts which was difficult to start with. Through this course, I also gained significant knowledge about how our world works and how it should work. It forced me to consider things I haven't in the past and realize that we live in a very non-ideal world.

response_text: The class enhances my knowledge on Bayesian epistemology. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course really developed public speaking and conversation skills, where the lectures tended to be student-led, with presentations essentially in every class. Learning how different figures interpret knowledge, such as Descartes and Kukla, challenged the way I view knowledge and how I should approach learning. This taught me to be more critical and skeptical of things in a good way, where I shouldn't believe everything I read and see. The public speaking skills also proved to be very useful, as I have trouble with public speaking, and having a presentation to do allowed me to practice and practice before ultimately having to present to the class and explain the reading I was assigned.

response_text: I learned the dominant and foundational stances on philosophy of science, the mind, and religion from Descartes to Gould to Chalmers. I learned the specific structures of arguments like that of Descartes' epistemology, Plantinga's rebuttal to naturalistic evolution, and Jackson's qualia argument against reductive physicalism. I was given the space to show my understanding of these stances and practice synthesizing my thoughts on the matter.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course is one of my favorite classes that I've taken at Duke. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Deconstructing complex philosophical/biological/physical arguments into palatable simple ones. The essay prompts broke down these concepts and I'm definitely going to be breaking down complicated concepts in a similar way that the professor did for future difficult essays. 
2. Understanding of neuroscience -- I'm not a neuroscience major and so I had no prior knowledge on how the brain worked at all. Getting to hold a human brain in my own hands was really special and I thought that the level of information that we could get was varied enough that a neuroscience major would learn something and a newbie like me could as well. 
3. One of my biggest insights into the class was being truly captivated by my fellow Duke peers' intellect. Many of us came from different majors and backgrounds and every person added such an interest take to the conversations. I was truly impressed with the depth of knowledge and philosophical thinking of my peers.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was my first ever philosophy class, and I would highly recommend it for anybody wanting to explore the subject. I learned how to think very deeply about some of the biggest questions, write detailed papers on philosophical arguments, and perhaps most importantly, how to ask questions and work towards the answer.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Wow, this class was so much better than I anticipated. I truly enjoyed learning about the intersections between science and religion, in a way that held space for all opinions, faiths, and backgrounds. I didn't feel like one faith or perspective was pressed onto us, and I learned how to dive into my thoughts and mind and truly decide where I stood on issues. I learned how complex conversations surrounding evolution truly are through the different evolutionary theories-- I did not realize how much of evolutionary theory was not agreed upon, because in high school it seemed like Darwinian- natural selection was the main and agreed upon definition of evolution. Also, I have never taken a philosophy class before, and I am so glad I took this one, because I learned about various ancient philosophers, how to contrast their ideas, and specifically learned about their ideas of the mind and God, which I find fascinating as a Neuroscience student. Finally, we went to Prof. Len White's brain lab, and I had so much fun going in the context of this course. Looking at the biological brain, but harboring these deep questions about religion and what it means to be human in the back of my mind from our readings, was truly remarkable.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Critical Analysis of Interdisciplinary Themes: I developed the ability to critically evaluate how neuroscience and religion intersect, particularly in understanding the neurological basis of spiritual experiences and how these are perceived in various cultural contexts.
2. Integrative Thinking: This course emphasized synthesizing diverse perspectives from scientific literature, philosophical texts, and theological frameworks to address complex questions about the human condition.
3. Effective Argumentation: I learned to craft arguments that bridge empirical evidence with abstract reasoning, enabling thoughtful discourse on topics that often evoke polarizing views, as exhibited during class seminar and long papers.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Watkins had us write reading responses to gauge our understanding, as well as three papers (each one had multiple prompts to choose from). The format allowed us to gain understanding on multiple texts as well as choose a topic we developed a strong interest in for our paper topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor made it super engaging, giving everyone an opportunity to give their views. I really enjoyed this model as I learned so much from my peers as well. Additionally, the guest lecturers that were invited to our class were very inspiring!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Watkins would move the desks so everyone could face each other, fostering better and more inclusive class discussions! I feel I was better able to listen to my peers' ideas and respond to their questions. I learned a lot of names of my classmates, which I don't feel is normally the case, and it was fun. Also, Prof. Watkins always held office hours, and doing so showed be that he was very determined to provide us students support, even if that meant taking away his personal work time. I could tell that when a guest speaker came (this is a part of the class I enjoyed-- the diverse and high number of intelligent and renowned guest speakers), Prof. Watkins was genuinely excited for US to get to interact with them.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Learning facilitated by...1. the notetaking guides, 2. Prof. Watkins' responsiveness over email and in office hours, 3. really interesting essay prompts and reading responses, 4. cool guest speakers... I would keep all of these!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Watkins was great!! Truly an incredible professor who made coming to an 8:30 enjoyable. I liked his structure with a reading assignment (and sometimes a very short reading response) and then a class discussion on the reading. But these were very low-stakes and unstressful conversations where he had a set of discussion questions and prompts ready to promote conversation and debate. Professor Watkins did a wonderful job keeping the class engaged and interested in the material with several guest lecturers and class visits. We even got to go to Dr. White's brain lab in DIBS!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
QUESTION ONE:
1. Engaging Lectures: Both the instructor's dynamic lectures and his incorporation of incredible guest lectures combined clear explanations of scientific concepts with thought-provoking questions that encouraged deeper exploration, in a non-conventional lecture format.
Discussion-Based Learning: The emphasis on open discussion allowed students to express diverse viewpoints and refine their arguments collaboratively. After each comment, the instructor maintained the ideal balance between validating his students' beliefs, further fostering an environment in which communication is valid, and also challenging them, asking follow-up questions intended with gauging their depth of analysis.
QUESTION TWO (Components to Retain):
1. Interdisciplinary Readings: Including a blend of neuroscience papers, religious texts, and philosophical essays was invaluable for a holistic learning experience. I will most definitely be re-reading my favorites of the one's he provided, like Lucretius and Plantinga. Not a single reading was short of exceedingly awe-provoking.
Interactive Class Discussions: These fostered a sense of intellectual curiosity among students, compelling me to take the class' complex commentary on the workings of the world with me everywhere I go as I continue to grapple with pressing inquiries, like the pursuit for meaning and the epistemological explanation for existence.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
Very stimulating! Not too much work but interactive in the best way. Really
enjoyed all the resources put into the course as well as the guest speakers. Made for a great time.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More questions posed to class during the seminars (also, I don't understand why this class was not coded as Seminar) instead of just lecture material about the readings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class exposed us to texts that we wouldn't familiarly be exposed to, specifically as the majority of our class were science- or math-based majors.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The questions we attempted to answer in this class, reading and talking about different philosophers' views really made the class very intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because we did not just read and listen to prominent philosophers and biologists and priests (etc.), but we directly contrasted their views to find nuances between theories of the world and God. It made me realize how empiricism is another school of thought, and our current world might be biased towards it. But there is something undeniably visceral about the human experience, that cannot be explained by science, at least not right now, and so there must be room for some higher power... this is a kind of conversation we would have in class! They were so engaging and interesting!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because it pushed me to think outside of my existing beliefs and really consider why I believe what I do. People in the class respectfully disagreed all the time, and Prof. Watkins created an environment where this was very allowed and accepted.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class provided the rare opportunity to discuss many difficult topics with no fear of judgment. For example, we were able to discuss evolution and natural selection, both complimenting and criticizing the theory, something I haven't been able to do in many other science courses at Duke.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Class discussions made this class stimulating.

response_text: the readings! they were extremely unqiue and provided a comprehensive but nuanced view of the world

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussions were purely opinion based which I thought was super unique to this class and made it very engaging.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating because each day wasn't the same -- we'd have guest lectures and even got to go into the brain lab at the DIBS!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was incredibly stimulating because it tackled the complexity of pressing humanitarian issues, such as how neuroscience can inform our understanding of spiritual experiences, moral decision-making, and even societal frameworks like justice and empathy. By addressing questions like the neural basis of compassion or the interplay between faith and reason, the course engaged with topics that felt both intellectually profound and deeply relevant to contemporary challenges.

response_text: Great course and great instruction!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE THIS CLASS! IT IS SO AMAZING. I think it is the best TI class. I love how small the class setting is, so you get to know your classmates and where they stand on topics. The content is unique and unlike any class I have taken before. Yet- for any STEM major, it truly overlaps with many fields in astounding ways. For instance, as a neuro major, I know I will take the philosophical conclusions about the mind and body of Descartes into my studies.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: TAKE IT! This course is one of my favorites I've taken at Duke. It pushed me to think about the world in a different way, and I've come out with different opinions about the world than when I entered. Definitely a great use of time & you will learn a lot.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: 100% take it!!!! If you're a neuro major looking for an easy and fun elective, this is the perfect course. There were 10 short (1 page) reading responses and 3 longer essays (5-7 pages) as well as participation. Amazing class, amazing professor, and fascinating material. Professor Watkins genuinely cares about his students and the material he is teaching so he works very hard to facilitate conversation and keep the class engaged.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: this is a wonderful course that thelps you think deeply about the world around you! i would definitely recommend

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you buy in and allow yourself to try to find different perspectives that is the only way you will be able to get the most out of this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it! It really made me think about what I believe, and I learned a lot about common theories, past and present, regarding these topics.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is a unique and intellectually rewarding journey that challenges you to think deeply about the intersections of science and spirituality, true to its classification as a 'transformative ideas' course. If you’re curious about how neuroscience can inform age-old philosophical and theological questions—or vice versa—this is the perfect class to broaden your horizons. Be prepared for stimulating discussions and to leave with a richer, more nuanced understanding of the human experience.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. I've learnt, at least the foundations of seven different religions and traditions. They're all very interesting and offer valuable insight on how to approach different aspects of the good life.2. I've learnt to pick and choose more effectively. The seven different traditions and religions offer important lessons on different aspects of life. I agree with some, and disagree with others. For example, I appreciate the pragmatism of Stoicism (I think of myself as stoic to an extent), but some things to me are not indifferents, they're simply bad. I prefer Confucianism's focus on ritual in dealing with loss.3. I've learnt to appreciate writing more. We did a lot of writing in this class, particularly with the jounral entries and the many notes and questions we did in class. It's brought back a lesson I learnt from my old writing teaching: "writing is thinking". I've done a lot of thinking through writing in this class.

response_text: The lectures are not particularly stimulating. Professor Antepuli, who taught us about Islam, was the only one I always wanted to hear more from, because of how engaging of a lecturer he was. I would suggest a total revamp of the lectures: more guest lecturers and case studies or real-world examples related to the religious concepts discussed (prompting us to apply the knowledge to practical situations). As well as the use of multimedia elements such as videos, documentaries, and interactive simulations to supplement traditional lectures and field trips to religious sites or events, allowing students to experience and observe religious practices firsthand.

response_text: The class truly has the power to transform ideas. The course is a truly one of one experience for sophomores, in this critical time of our lives. The teachings of various traditions allowed me to see the world in a whole different light.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to understand different points of view and relate with each other to find common ground in thought. In light of several issues concurrently happening around the world, this class was a breath of fresh air that allowed civil conversation organized by the amazing professors. The retreat also was placed at such a perfect time when I was studying for midterms, helping me escape the Duke bubble. Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. And this class reminded me of how important human interaction and conversation is.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think the lack of communication and expectations between students and the professors has made the class a little less stimulating. The interest I and others would gain from lectures is often overshadowed by the confusion regarding deadlines and grading expectations. I know it is hard to coordinate a class with so many students and teachers, but sometimes assignment due dates feel rushed. I have heard such amazing things about this class and felt a little disappointed with how it actually went. The retreat was absolutely amazing, and I believe the TI program has the potential to keep that energy going the entire class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

The retreat also was placed at such a perfect time when I was studying for midterms, helping me escape the Duke bubble. Life at Duke isn't in any way representative of how real life is meant to be viewed or taken. Life is meant to be good. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
1) Weekly readings with the questions—really prompted us to actually delve into the readings.
2) Dialogue Groups & DG performances—great way to meet people!
3) THE RETREAT! Such a great embodiment of TI's values, & really helped me relax as a sophomore & meet other people & experience the importance of staying present.
4) Check system for questions & journal entries—removes pressure of thinking in a "correct" way.
5) Dialogue between traditions—having the professors representing the traditions have actual conversations together at the front of the lecture hall.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Duke students often refer to an easy class as a good class. If you want a relatively easy class take this class. If you want a somewhat intellectually stimulating class, I recommend taking a different course. Though the teachers were interesting, the lack of student engagement will impede your own experience. There is a required overnight retreat and a dialogue section weekly which aren't noted on the course description. This course requires you to submit 2 questions a week on canvas, 10 reflective journal entries, 1 acting performance, and 1 final paper. Overall it is a very manageable class. You get what you put into this course, so know that before enrolling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: learned different philosophical concepts, the applications of these concepts, and how to look at the world through different perspectives

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I worked on my philosophical writing skills. Professor Hazelwood frequently laments the inaccessibility/pretentiousness of philosophical writing, so by constantly reading examples of good and bad prose or and argumentation, as well as writing our own philosophical papers, I left the class with a better understanding of how to write effective and readable philosophy papers.
2. I developed my argumentation skills. With two in-class debates worked into the curriculum, we had a chance to put our ideas to the test against our fellow students. This was a great exercise in research, argument preparation, and effective delivery of complex ideas. 
3. As an applied ethics course, this class helped bridge the gap between what we learn in classrooms and how we live outside school. The "Living Ethically" semester-long project, as well as the content of many of the readings, helped to demonstrate the link between philosophy and praxis and pushed me to reflect harder on my everyday habits.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: learned background philosophical concepts, learned approaches for evaluating the morality of my own actions and ghg emissions, and I learned about environmental philosophies such as the land ethic and ecofeminism

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: knowledge in environmental ethics in various aspects (animal rights, restorative ecology, ecofeminism, value ethics, scientific methodology etc.)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I got better at knowing how to condense my points into a couple of sentences, instead of talking myself in circles.I learned how to craft arguments in a debate format. Specifically, when it comes to knowing how not to walk into traps, knowing when to let logical facilities talk for themselves, and appeal to an audience.I learned how to value when my perspective was not valued. There are times when it is important for all voices to be heard, but there are also times when arguments can only be made in the context of deep personal connection to a topic.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I feel that I gained a thorough understanding of all topics covered in the course, including (but not limited to) the arguments for and against novel ecosystems, the ways Indigenous practices can be incorporated into or complement Western scientific practices, and the implications of Aldo Leopold's 'Land Ethic.' In addition to the topics covered, my ability to discern arguments within philosophical writing was greatly enhanced, and I gained considerable experience formulating and expressing personal ideas and arguments orally.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: the professors often asked a question and mostly left it to the students to formulate their opinions which made the class more engaging

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The pacing of readings was very manageable. Professor Hazelwood changed the reading quiz structure at the midpoint of the semester in response to student feedback and I think the final structure was very effective. I liked the reading quizzes because as long as you did the reading, it'll be easy, but if you didn't, you'll do poorly, so I found them to be fair and manageable, but by including an option for annotations in lieu of a quiz this was very accommodating to students who do the readings but may just not be great test-takers. I loved the debates, they were fun. The living ethically assignment was a great way to tie class concepts to the outside world, which is kind of the whole point of the class so that was great too. Podcast was a cool chance to discuss class concepts further with a real expert in the field. Honestly every part of the class was great and felt like it had a very intentional reason for being included in the curriculum.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: regular readings and quizzes were good for ensuring engagement although still manageable. Instruction and in class discussions were very engaging

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was by far my favorite class of the semester, and a large part of that was due to Caleb. The learning environment was very welcoming. As someone who has never taken a philosophy class at Duke, I was worried that I would struggle to grasp the concepts and fall behind, but Caleb was a great teacher who explained the concepts well and made this class an enjoyable experience for me. I like that the class had a lot of different types of assignments, like the vlog assignment and the podcast assignment, that kept it interesting and pushed the boundaries of what I usually do in classes.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that the quizzes at the beginning of each class were very valuable in making sure that everyone understood the material and came to class prepared to talk. I have been in a lot of classes where nobody actually does the reading, and the class ends up being the professor lecturing at the classroom, with very little room for actual deep and thoughtful discussion. The concept of having a quiz at the beginning of class is scary, and was at times stressful, but it did ensure that class ran very smoothly and was full of actual thoughtful conversation, as opposed to simply being a recap of the text.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Hazelwood's teaching style, while strong from the start, wonderfully adapted to the needs and culture of the class, greatly enhancing our ability to engage with and consume content. For example, Professor Hazelwood would provide reading assessments to determine our engagement with written material prior to class. After receiving feedback requesting a different form of assessment more accessible for those who may have testing anxiety (or anything else other than their understanding of the reading that would limit their ability to perform will on the quizzes), Professor Hazelwood immediately provided an option that allowed thorough annotations of the text to stand in for the reading assessments. I would love for the annotating option to be available in the future, and I found having both the quiz and annotation options to be very beneficial to my learning.Additionally, Professor Hazelwood's classroom management was perhaps the greatest asset for my learning. He expertly guided discussion, providing helpful information and direction where needed. I truly felt that my classmates and I were learning from each other and working towards 'the answers' (as much as there are in philosophy), and there was always a sense of accomplishment when we realized we had 'gotten' a point. Professor Hazelwood was excellent at affirming our viewpoints (or constructively and kindly pointing us in a different direction). The discussion based classroom, particularly due to Professor Hazelwood's involvement, really helped me to retain content, as it ensured that all of the students logically work through readings, rather than being handed a point or simply memorizing an argument structure.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: the professor often asked a question and mostly left it to the students to formulate their opinions which made the class more engaging

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: See above comment about Nasher visit (that was awesome and so perfectly on topic for the class), Professor is a funny and engaging lecturer, every reading felt valuable and I learned something new from it, and there was plenty of discussions (as opposed to just lecturing) in each class. It was the epitome of intellectual exploration because sometimes we'd get on a tangentially related topic that everyone found interesting and we'd just see it through and keep discussing it even if it wasn't on the agenda, which meant we got to cover not just the assigned readings but all the different ideas students had that were sparked by the readings.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: very aligned with my interests, discussion based, thought provoking readings

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topics were really interesting, and Caleb was great at engaging the class and creating challenging and intellectually stimulation discussions.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was very stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The readings each week covered a topic I was either only vaguely aware of or that I had never encountered before. It was extremely refreshing to hear about new content, particularly from a variety of perspectives. Professor Hazelwood did an excellent job of curating our readings such that each week we often had papers 'for' the topic at hand and other papers 'against' which enabled us to engage with each other and have productive disagreements. I really appreciated hearing both sides of various debates, and it made class discussion much more intellectually stimulating. The content covered was challenging, but not beyond our capabilities, which also made the class more engaging. I also feel that Professor Hazelwood's personality contributed to students' engagement in the course. While serious when necessary, his warm demeanor and humor was excellent at drawing students in to participate and feel confident in presenting their viewpoints. While in the past I have been terrified of 'cold calling', on the somewhat rare occasion Professor Hazelwood used it, I felt empowered (rather than anxious) to share my answer or even admit my lack of understanding on a specific aspect of a topic. Professor Hazelwood did a great job of bringing everyone into the conversation and validating viewpoints, and very quickly our class time turned into free-flowing discussions where nearly everyone thoughtfully engaged several times.

response_text: Best professor and learning environment that I have had at Duke, by a mile. Caleb makes everyone in the class feel like they are a person with something valuable to share to the conversation, as opposed to just a student consuming and regurgitating material. I don't think that I have felt as close to a group of students and professor as I have in this class. Caleb made me look forward to going to class twice each week, and I knew I was going to learn something new and hear different perspectives. Caleb also has a clear mastery of his craft, not only in the philosophy of biology, but in a speaker and philosophical interlocutor.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend taking this course. It perfectly blends environmental science and philosophy, and is extremely informative and applicable to current events. Additionally, the class is very engaging (and fun). Personally, it was the coveted class of the semester that I really looked forward to attending. While there are a couple of group projects, I felt the work required for them wasn't stressful. Professor Hazelwood is a very fair grader, provides quality feedback to support his grading decisions, and is also willing to provide extra credit opportunities. It's definitely a class where the work you put in directly results in your grade, so as long as you do your assignments with good effort, you should do well in the course. Professor Hazelwood is also extremely helpful in office hours and provides thorough and detailed feedback.

In addition, I learned different normative commitments and questions of public policy that go along with them including utilitarianism, Rawlsian distributive justice, libertarianism, and Sen's capability theory.

I do like the fact that we have breaks in the middle, since it allows to reset our learning capabilities (enhance them, in a way), and take in what we learned from the first half of class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Rosenberg was incredibly engaging with the class and did a great job of making dense political philosophy digestible for people who have never taken a philosophy (or economics) class before. question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Examined science from a philosophical perspective: why is it reliable and different from other ways of knowing about the world
1. In the beginning part of the course, we read and discussed different theories of a good and reliable scientific method from Positivism to Karl Popper.
2. Then we viewed science from a broader angle, starting from Thomas Kuhn, to see how it actually progresses
3. In the las month, we saw modern issues with trust in science and animal experiment debates.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

course: PHIL-242S-01 : PROBLEMS IN PHIL OF SCIENCE.PHIL-242S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Discussion topics are interesting as they are fundamental to how we view the world. At times, student participation seemed very low- lots of questions were asked and followed by long pauses (maybe due to confusion or poorly phrased questions).

course: PHIL-242S-01 : PROBLEMS IN PHIL OF SCIENCE.PHIL-242S-01.
question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was very intellectually stimulating. For one, philosophy is in many ways inherently intellectually stimulating by the nature of the subject because of the way it centers around asking difficult questions, thinking about difficult ideas, and trying to create intellectual answers to questions.

course: PHIL-242S-01 : PROBLEMS IN PHIL OF SCIENCE.PHIL-242S-01.

course: PHIL-242S-01 : PROBLEMS IN PHIL OF SCIENCE.PHIL-242S-01.

course: PHIL-242S-01 : PROBLEMS IN PHIL OF SCIENCE.PHIL-242S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you don't have prior knowledge about philosophy of science or probability, this class will be a struggle. The readings are dense and kind of assume you have a baseline understanding of the concepts. However, the class itself was interesting and discussions helped with parsing out the material

course: PHIL-242S-01 : PROBLEMS IN PHIL OF SCIENCE.PHIL-242S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course has a very narrow subject area, so I suggest taking it only if it you are interested in the objectivity vs subjectivity of science and the philosophy of causation. Readings are interesting but at times a lot to grasp. Much of the course is student-led and you should expect to have to speak frequently and present multiple times. Exams were challenging for philosophy and require memorization and critical thinking.

course: PHIL-242S-01 : PROBLEMS IN PHIL OF SCIENCE.PHIL-242S-01.
question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This course is definitely difficult, particularly if you take it a first course in philosophy like I did. That said, I learned a lot, the professors are incredible, and the nature of the content is useful both for researchers/practitioners in science but also for even a day to day understanding of how to think about and interact with science and purported explanations of causation.

course: PHIL-242S-01 : PROBLEMS IN PHIL OF SCIENCE.PHIL-242S-01.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely learned a lot in this course and was able to continue to grow my thinking and the concept of game theory. One specific thing I learned in the course is the importance of writing effectively. This means, less is more, and conveying your point with evidence in the least amount of words is the key to a successful writer. You want what you are saying to be impactful, and making it come across in that manner is important. Another thing I learned is game theory, and how to play different types of games and strategies. Before this class, I had minimal knowledge of game theory, and now can relate the concepts I learned in this class to my microeconomics course as well. Lastly, I think another skill that I learned from this class is correlating these games and strategies into human behavior and understanding how people make their decisions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I enjoyed thinking about the intersection of economics, politics, and philosophy. I learned that these three branches are interconnected, I learned different views on governance, and I learned to questions beliefs about political structure that I had held before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new way of thinking through issues using an economic lens. As someone who has never taken a course in economics before, this was a novel concept for me. I also learned about the concept of the Prisoner's Dilemma, and most importantly how to apply it in a real-world context. Lastly, I learned about the importance of the combination of Politics, Philosophy, and Economics (PPE) when attacking complex problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to compare and contrast different philosophical readings, how to apply economic frameworks to political issues, and we learned about styles of voting and government.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Exploring the intersections between various disciplines (Politics, Economics, Philosophy). Interdisciplinary approach allowed me to explore ideas from a new perspective and use critical thinking skills to make judgements

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the median voter theorem, different forms of justice, and the origins of social contracts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to combine aspects of multiple disciplines 
2. How to quickly find specific information from dense readings 
3. How to write commentaries using description, analysis, and judgement

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have taken a class with Prof. Salsman before and something that he is really exceptional at is making individual problems/ideas very multi-dimensional. For example, how you can look at one concept and examine 5 different viewpoints. I also really like how this class is broken up into a bunch of smaller units. Makes the ideas easier to process and think about as well as stay on top of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about game theory, the impact of politics in the economy, and market competition.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First off, in this course I learned the similarities and differences in ideology of philosophers such as Locke, Hobbes and Rousseau. I also learned about game theory, and which situations in the real world possess those same incentives. Along with that, I learned about the "Pareto optimal" outcome, as well as a Nash equilibrium. Lastly, the course covers what government and market failures are, and how we know when they take place. Overall, I learned how to think more philosophically about economic and political policies as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: New ways of thinking. I enjoyed learning about political philsophers like Hume and Locke. I enjoyed most of the readings and I thought they provided a lot of unique thought, most notably in the realm of human decsion making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I built on previous knowledge to better understand spatial and theoretical explanations of political economy. I learned how to implement conceptions of justice, marginal markets, and price theories in academic and practical philosophies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new away to approach the world, through a lense of always asking by what standard, and through incorporating a multifaceted approach.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Problems often have multiple lenses that they can be viewed through. Depending on which angle issues are approached through, different solutions can be more obvious than others. Synthesizing these different views is a difficult task that often has no "right" conclusion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to analyze and dissect articles and documents and formulate critiques/responses to them.
I learned about different viewpoints on justice and economics from esteemed thinkers throughout history.
I leaned how to write my own opinions with regards to ideas presented in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Essay writing, critical analysis, open-mindedness during debate.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think logically, I was taught the importance of having logical evidence for my beliefs, I learned about game theory and how to apply it to real life interactions

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course helped me learn a lot about the beginnings of PPE. Specifically, I learned a lot about the differences between spontaneous order and deliberate design, the spheres that make up our daily lives, the Median Voter Theorem, the state of nature, and the nature of the state. I have learned differing opinions on many of these topics from different authors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Evaluating political and economic theories through multiple lenses, connecting political theories/phenomena to economic ones, game theory

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Interpreting texts and their associated concepts across the PP&E methodology
2. Writing and describing argumentation across broad topics in the course while providing my insights and thoughts on the content.
3. Communicating and discussing PP&E related ideas, learning how to cross the interdisciplinary nature of the issues we covered.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed knowledge in many topics through Philosophy and Economics. I enjoyed the profits and competition lectures, as well as the justice and equality lectures. I thought at the end of the year when we had more "discussion" based classes, I was very engaged and was encouraged to participate more.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Salsman taught us to think critically and evaluate primary sources. A lot of the readings took analysis and the topics covered required knowledge that we learned through lecture and the readings.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned more about basic philosophical concepts with regards to economics and politics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained a greater understanding of social cooperation and coordination, market/government interrelations, and application of distributive justice. Overall, this course provided a multi-disciplinary framework through which to think about societal issues. It drew from philosophical, political, and economic perspectives.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Learned about crony capitalism, the Median Voter Theorem, the role and "extent" of government, different critiques of capitalism, economic perspectives including Say, Marx, Locke, Keynes, etc., and game theory.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed the ability to integrate economic, philosophic, and political ideas.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the history of neuroscience (Aristotle, ventricular doctrine...), whether the brain can be functionally localized, lesion studies and brain function, brain area, fMRI controversies, reductionism, the brain as a computer, the Marr framework, mechanistic explanations of neuroscience, memory, consciousness, and free will among other topics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned:
1) A lot about the history of psychology and neuroscience, how they intersected and are undergirded by philosophy, and the origins of a lot of the ideas about the brain we have today
2) To think more critically about neuroscientific methods, considering the limitations of different instruments and other methodological approaches
3) A lot more about some foundational neuroscience and psychology case studies that I have heard of but not engaged with nearly as critically as we did here

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take, even if you don't know Chinese language or culture because you don't need to at all. It is just a philosophy course, and an amazing one at that. Engaging in philosophy has been such a beneficial experience for me, and frankly I think a philosophy course ought to be required for every student, especially considering the course requirement changes being made.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Absolutely take it. Light on work, not because the course is easy, but because the professor trusts you to spend time grappling with these topics yourself rather than doing endless assignments on them. IF you understand something, five pages should be enough to talk about it to an informed reader.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: You get what you want to put into the class, if you're interested in philosophy, either as a major or just an interest, I think this class is an excellent introduction into the general ideas and themes found within Chinese philosophy. I'd recommend for those who want to engage with the content, most of it is going to be from internal reflection and consideration and some from class discussion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a knowledge of eras, how those eras and the events during shaped the thoughts of philosophers during those times, and how those philosophers built thoughts on previous thoughts. And all of this knowledge was achieved through reading prominent, classic literature that we were able to learn how to interpret and interact with in order to gain philosophical insights from them. It was very interesting how each philosopher's circumstances drove their thinking, and how that thinking was able to be built upon and developed over time throughout many more eras and philosophers. And it was all about arguably the most important question one can ask themselves: what is the meaning of life? I was able to learn more about philosophers who thought there is an inherent meaning to life and what that meaning looked like to them, that there is not meaning to life, or that certain factors/experiences/mindsets could give one meaning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The conflict between ideological loyalty and material harm prevention—whether in the regulation of AI-generated disinformation or in the defense of capitalist market structures—reveal the same pattern repeats: ideology-first positions prioritize abstract principles even when faced with clear evidence of harm, while material-first positions seek to address concrete damage, even at the cost of ideological purity. This essay will show how this underlying dynamic shapes both debates over AI regulation and the longstanding capitalism versus communism controversy.In the current debates surrounding AI regulation, especially around deepfake imagery and disinformation, the divide is sharp. Anti-regulation advocates adopt an ideology-first stance, prioritizing principles of free speech absolutism and market autonomy. Organizations like the Cato Institute frame any attempt to regulate AI content as a slippery slope to censorship or dangerous government overreach. Similarly, the narrative that "innovation must be free from interference" dismisses the material harms caused by AI disinformation — such as manipulated election outcomes, voter suppression, and the erosion of public trust. The underlying ideological commitment to liberty and free market operation remains firm even in the face of mounting evidence that AI technologies, left unchecked, can profoundly destabilize democratic institutions.Conversely, pro-regulation advocates adopt a material-first position, focusing not on preserving ideological purity, but on minimizing measurable harm. They prioritize policies like mandatory watermarking of AI-generated media, platform accountability for disinformation campaigns, and transparency requirements for algorithmic content distribution. Their arguments are grounded in concrete evidence: AI models have exacerbated biases in hiring, deepened misinformation flows, and enabled new forms of exploitation and surveillance. Rather than focusing on deontological arguments about abstract rights, material-first proponents insist that preventing real-world damage must take precedence, even if it entails some limitations on absolute free expression or market freedom.This structure mirrors the capitalism versus communism debate throughout the twentieth century. Capitalist apologetics frequently operated from an ideology-first perspective, framing free markets and competition as "natural" forces immune to political critique. Ideologies of meritocracy — that wealth and success reflect personal virtue — mystified systemic inequalities, obscuring the exploitation and structural violence embedded in global capitalism. Even as ecological collapse, labor precarity, and extreme wealth gaps became more visible, defenders of market ideology dismissed these harms as "externalities" rather than evidence of fundamental flaws. Their loyalty remained not to empirical outcomes but to the abstract sanctity of market competition.On the other side, critiques of capitalism — including socialist and communist thought — adopt a material-first approach. These critiques prioritize harm reduction: alleviating poverty, protecting ecological systems, ensuring workers' rights, and reducing systemic inequality. They are less concerned with preserving the ideological purity of economic "freedom" and more concerned with minimizing the tangible suffering produced by capitalist systems. Whether through labor protections, wealth redistribution, or environmental regulation, material-first critiques demand that abstract ideals yield when faced with material devastation.
