question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In the traditional model of ideological control, elites dominate mental production by distributing first-order ideological content: direct messages about what is true, good, or desirable. However, this is no longer the only — or even the primary — mechanism. In the contemporary world, not only does mental production distribute first-order ideology, but also the enforcement of second-order ideology additionally distributes first-order ideology. Seemingly neutral frameworks like "free speech," "anti-misinformation," and "anti-hate speech" are second-order ideologies that not only prescribe how the media should distribute first-order content but universalize first-order values through their enforcement. Thus, the public inherits first-order ideologies not only from the media itself but derive them from universal prescriptions of what kinds of communication are deemed legitimate.Consider "misinformation" enforcement. During the Cold War, elites not only flooded the media with anti-communist messages; they also framed sympathy toward communism itself as "misinformation" or "subversion." Thus, communism being bad was not only simply conveyed through the arguments the media made, but through ruling the discussion of alternatives as inherently illegitimate and a form of misinformation. In this context, "misinformation" as a second-order ideology was a direct extension of a first-order ideological battle: capitalism versus communism.In today's technocratic context, however, "misinformation" serves a different second-order function. The contemporary enforcement of "misinformation" on the surface seems to be a simple second-order filter for accuracy. However, such a filter spreads a universalist belief in objective truth — the idea that there exists a singular, recognizable reality that must be protected and disseminated for the sake of social cohesion and progress. Through this enforcement, public life becomes organized around a metaphysics of universal objectivity, where being properly informed is valued above all else.The antithesis of this is free speech absolutism. Media and education have long glorified individual liberty, often portraying censorship as synonymous with tyranny. The enforcement of free speech absolutism — treating any regulation of speech as dangerous — quietly installs this ideological lesson as a universal framework: that freedom is valued above all else, even at the expense of others' feelings, social cohesion, or truth itself. In this framework, we value our freedom over information integrity, emotional safety, and democratic stability, perpetuating the first-order libertarian ideal without openly stating it.Similarly, anti-hate speech policies reveal how second-order frameworks distribute first-order ideology. Modern pluralistic societies emphasize the protection of marginalized groups, and content celebrating diversity and inclusion is everywhere. The enforcement of "anti-hate" regulations carries this deep implication: that emotional harm and subjective feelings deserve institutional protection. Thus, anti-hate enforcement teaches that our feelings should be valued — that emotional safety is not merely a private concern, but a political and communicative standard that reshapes the public sphere.In each case, second-order enforcement distributes first-order ideology by naturalizing its assumptions about legitimacy, safety, harm, and truth. What appears as neutral procedural management — combating misinformation, protecting speech, ensuring emotional safety — is in fact the continuation of elite interests by other means. Thus, mental production is no longer simply about distributing beliefs; it is about embedding frameworks that structure the conditions of belief themselves. Today's ideological domination operates not only on the level of what we think, but even more profoundly on what kind of relationship to truth, harm, and freedom we are allowed to have.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course showed me that the concepts, categories, and terms used by biologists are murkier than I assumed. Coming from a stronger philosophy than biology background, I also learned a good deal about subfields of biology such as evolutionary psychology. I was introduced to terms like species concepts and learned to think about them critically through papers arguing for, and against, their existence. I learned to think through the philosophical implications of a conclusion, such as whether it requires backwards causation or contains any contradictions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I would say this class first and foremost develops attention to detail. The readings we complete are dense and, for many, the first exposure we have to scientific papers in this category. Many of the papers we read build upon topics that are covered in introductory bio courses (201/202), but they give us a lot of the philosophical and biological grounding that we do not get exposure to. I would say this course also develops communication. In this class, we have been encouraged to speak in an open and inviting environment. Our class atmosphere is light and fun, and with that, comes an ability to dive more deeply into content and not jump over any confusions. The third would be critical thinking. This course allows us to question what we have learned through providing us with readings that give us a better understanding of the discourse within the broader scientific community, as well as gives us the space to compare and contrast varying ideas.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

There was also a reading comprehension quiz at the start of each class. Although this wasn't my favorite thing, it did incentivize me to read more carefully. In this way I did understand the papers better which I think led to my enjoyment of the class. For this reason I think they should be kept for future semesters

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class as a whole is structured to maximize intellectual stimulation. From the papers we read, to in-class discussions, to class activities, and projects, the class allows for a lot of room to engage with the material. It was seen from our final Kahoot—the class clearly retained many of the main ideas (as well as specific details) of a number of the topics and specific readings we covered. I would also posit that the final project (a research paper) is a very wonderful way to draw together some of the ideas and skills we developed throughout the semester. Initially, I had an idea for a paper. Then, Caleb pointed me towards some readings that he thought would be helpful. As I read more and more literature, I reworked my thesis and came up with an entirely new project proposal and ran with that! In speaking with Caleb to revise, I was able to readjust my lenses once again. He provides a wonderful opportunity to learn and really delve into what scientific writing and understanding is.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

The topics are much more about semantics in biology and are pretty useless when considering real applications in biology.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Caleb's teaching style was perhaps the best thing about the course. You can clearly tell he has a deep love and knowledge of the subject matter and shared this with the students in a way that also got them engaged and excited about these questions. He used various engaging assignment styles, such as debates, group discussions, and journal style writing to expose us to the broader practice of academic philosophy. His specific teaching style is one that simultaneously embraces the interests of students while also pushing them to follow their thinking to its conclusions and even go beyond it. Specifically, I think his assignment in which we had to interview a current biologist was one of the most stimulating and rewarding discussions I've had with a professor during my time at university and something I think certainly should continue in the future of his courses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned about Multiple Worlds theory, Free Logic, Intuitionists Logic, and similarity sphere to name a few concepts.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of new logics and proof techniques.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Solving tableaus; rigorous logical arguments; and the connections between philosophy, mathematics, and computer science from the final course projects

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: New methods of logic, tableaux and truth tables, and thinking about logic applications.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Logic, Critical Thinking and Deductive Reasoning

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We covered a number of different systems of logic, all built on the foundation of "CPL" - classical propositional logic. Each model had upsides and downsides. Modal logic (K, CK, VK) could be used to think about potential truths and possibilities; first order logic (FOL, FL, CK, VK) could be used to consider more abstract logical statements; so on and so forth. Ultimately, every model had issues dealing with the conditional - "if" - and every approach to that had problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about attention in a philosophical context, I improved my understanding of how to read philosophical texts and read deeply, and I improved my ability to understand texts in relation to each other.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- i learned a new way of writing - writing as a process of thinking and discovery rather than argumentation - which really helped me deepen my understanding of the philosophy i learn in class
- The attention journals helped me ground my learning in everyday life and always apply things i learn with the help of attention
- This course really sparked my interest in literature and philosophy and allowed me to decide that i want to major in GCS

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about looking at literature through philosophy.
I came in with no prior knowledge of Weil, Beauvoir, and Murdoch, but I feel I have a very strong grasp on them and their philosophies now.
I also developed skills in creating a concise presentation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Just as Simone Weil wrote in her essays, in the right use of schoolwork, attention is extensively practiced. So I guess the most important three things I learned are attention to others and other things, Weil, Beauvoir, and Murdoch’s visions of existence, and of course essay writing methods.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Became intimately familiar with philosophies of Simone Weil, Simone de Beauvoir, and Iris Murdoch through close readings. Learned ethics in a way that was immediately applicable to everyday life. Gained insights about the influence of these thinkers on one another, particularly Simone Weil of whom I had close to no knowledge of before entering the course. One of my favorite things was when Professor Moi filled in historical/philosophical context around these thinkers (wartime, surrounding literature, Wittgenstein, Hegel, etc)--made it feel less like narrowing in on these random philosophers in a vacuum.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) I learned about the philosophies and moral frameworks of Weil, Murdoch, and Beauvoir
2) I recognized ways in which these philosophical theories resonated with me and have a fresh perspective on my own behavior and way of living. 
3) I have become more conscious of the ways in which I do and don't pay attention in my life, and have begun cultivating that skill in my own behavior.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really appreciated the openness to questions through discussions and the Slack channel, and I also enjoyed the handouts from the class presentations and slideshows.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- i loved the seminar structured way of teaching that was interspersed with explanations of other philosophers (ie i liked professor moi's connections of weil, beauvoir, and murdoch with wittgenstein, cavell, and plato) because they not only allowed me to think deeper about the concepts i learn, but also open up new territories for me to explore in the future
- the weekly attention journals are also very helpful, because it forces me to sit down and reflect on the philosophy and also put things i learn into practice (paying attention)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Moi encouraged genuine reflection with our attention journals. These were not graded on the A-F scale, which allowed them to be purely for our own building of the skill of attention without having to pander or have a grade in the back of our minds. I would definitely keep this part of the course. I also found Professor Moi's lectures interesting. The breaking up of the three philosophers into three separate parts rather than going between them also made them digestible so that they didn't get convoluted.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Absolutely, when the material gets a bit too hard, Professor Moi made slides to accommodate and overall the in-class discussions were very fruitful. And I really liked the idea of using Slack channel to talk about difficult concepts.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Smaller readings allowed me to pay closer attention to each text and get more out of subsequent lectures and discussions. I liked the attention journals as a way to keep me closely engaged with the texts throughout the week.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought that in terms of content, the course flowed quite nicely. I thought beginning with Weil and ending with Murdoch (from our big three names) was the ideal order, with Weil's concept of attention framing the whole course and Murdoch's vision-based moral theory bringing together attention and action, as well as offering a more realistic and individualized moral approach (compared to Weil's saintly expectations and Beauvoir's more politically-grounded perspective).

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

response_text: It's certainly a challenging course, and can feel a bit intimidating at times, but it also is extremely rewarding in that you'll end the semester with a thorough understanding of several important and relevant philosophical ideas.

response_text: The course definitely improved my ability to write both through the activity of writing (blog posts, the first essay), but moreso through an engagement with writers in an active manner that helped to inculcate what effective writing looks like and feels like. Most importantly, the course helped to teach me the importance of attention throughout my life, and to equip me with different tools for the training and use of attention.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this class if you are interesting in philosophy, literature, theory or anything related at all. Note that this is not a feminist philosophy class, more so a class about women philosophers. I think these are philosophers that are underrated in the academic canon, although Beauvoir is quite popular now. But definitely Simone Weil is an underrated writer and philosopher that everyone should read. Professor Moi is also a great teacher who understands students and the texts quite well. The amount of texts you read in this class is perfect. Long enough that you get a deep enough understanding of the philosopher, but also not too long so that it becomes unmanageable. The texts are also enlightening and perfectly difficult to understand so when you do get some insight it feels nice and illuminating.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to analyze current events from different perspectives, discuss/debate controversial topics in a constructive manner, and approach complex issues aiming towards potential solutions/responses.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class we had discussions of very politically controversial topics every week - I think that one main thing I learned from this teaching style was how to apply different frames of thought to the same issue. More specifically, we applied economic, political, and philosophical analysis to each topic that we reviewed during the course. So I learned to integrate different frameworks into one broader idea / topic. I also learned about different philosophies / approaches to life - for example the difference between egoism and altruism and how these two perspectives influence individuals' way of thinking about different phenomenon. Also, I particularly enjoyed when Professor Salsman opened up abvout his personal research and models on the financial economy and his financial crash predicting model - the finance discussion was particularly interesting to me.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Objectively debating
long essay writing
conceptualizing opposing viewpoints

response_text:
Learned how to address immigration issues

How individual autonomy is protected

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to synthesize politics, philosophy, and economics- as well as how to rigorously argue about philosophical readings.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussion-based classes were very helpful, as it allowed us to guide the conversations towards topics that we found most intriguing and express/questions our positions. I also appreciated that the syllabus was flexible and could be changed to better fit our interests.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that Professor Salsman does a uniquely good job in opening the floor of discussion to any and all thoughts and opinions - this is the only class I have EVER taken at Duke where I didn't feel I would be shunned and penalized for making certain conservative arguments that other Professor's typically do not accept or give a second thought. I think this made the class WAY more interesting, because it was the first class with a truly open discussion I have ever attended. I think universities and Duke in particular needs to work on not allowing professors to penalize students for their political opinions, and they should ask Salsman how to do this, because he did a fantastic job at moderating and encouraging discussion of diverse perspectives.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor made sure we were comfortable sharing our opinions in the class. He would provide background information and interject periodically to facilitate productive class discussions.

response_text: The teacher engaged us in vivid discussion with peers and had us stay up to date with reading with weekly conversations. The learning environment was facilitated very well and allowed for an open discussion.

response_text: This is a fantastic course that will teach you how to think differently about very relevant and controversial topics in society and politics.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have acquired the ability to read and interpret original works of philosophy and ethics. The three specific things that helped me learn include: my presentation, communication with classmates and discussion with Professor wong about my presentation.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: the difficulty of capturing the concepts in Chinese philosophy using English; how similar the Chinese thought can be to certain ancient greek thoughts; different possible readings of Plato that can be outside of "traditional" and fixed interpretation

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I like bringing together two traditions and focusing on the same topic

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Using analytic methods to compare various philosophies from eastern and western cultures.
2. Practicing my ability to breakdown complex information from scholarly sources and presenting those ideas to the classroom. 
3. Comparing social constraints of the ancient world to similar situations that occur in modern society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: - I become much more appreciative of Confucian texts and Kongzi himself, because of Ing's book The Invulnerability of Integrity/ our class discussion/ David's insights. I used to think that compared to Zhuangzi, there are so many attachments to norms and rituals and ought-to-dos which I find constricting. But after reading Ing's book, I love how he read Confucian texts in light of vulnerability and the tragic thesis—that there are ways in which relationships with meaningful others might compel tragic actions—and I also love how he, in citing Li Ling, offers an understanding of Kongzi as a misfit that is really touching --- "The Kongzi described by Li Ling is authoritative in his impossible convictions, charismatic in his frustrations, and inexplicably happy in his sorrows. These paradoxes seem to express a homelessness in which we are all at home, a somewhat awkward but familiar feeling...In this view, Kongzi is a misfit— his aspirations for transforming the world are incongruous with his experience in the world, and in this, he represents a common human experience. As such, by telling about Kongzi’s mismatch between his hopes and his experiences, it opens the possibility for us, his readers, to explore the (sometimes tragic) gap between our hopes and our experiences."- I appreciate the attention to the concept of "care" in both Platonic and Confucian texts. Previously I haven't paid much attention to how "care" is discussed in Republic, etc. and I also find it interesting how much attention both Plato and Confucians give to music and use music/sound as an analogy. I find the Confucian understanding of how harmony is a response of Qi and how it relates to response/responsiveness interesting— as well as the concept of accommodation, how one can relate to/care for another in the midst of radical difference or disagreement.- I also appreciate the opportunity to more closely engage with Zhuangzi, in thinking with him how one can respond to a world that is elusive and constantly shifting, escaping any attempt to pin it down—and being radically open to transformations beyond one's control. Reading Zhuangzi at this time is definitely an immense comfort.- bridge concept, refusal of dichotomies (refuse to choose a side)

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Due to my interdisciplinary background, I have learned how to combine classical Chinese ethics, Western ethics and modern applied ethical practices, and this has given me inspiration to start writing new articles in my fiels.

response_text: Both instructors chose relevant and engaging readings that they elaborated on in class. I thought the flow of content built on itself week-to-week very naturally.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
- super appreciate the feedback for presentations & always being generous with time & thoughts
- juicy slides are super helpful to follow along + easy to come back to later
- appreciate how the course is organized: how different philosophical traditions were being put into conversation with each other, structured around the theme of emotions; how the connections among different things we read were discussed so that we could easily see how the course content unfold; also appreciate how previous discussions and thoughts are incorporated into later stuff

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In our weekly assignments, we had to respond to the week's text(s) with a substantial critique without consulting any secondary literature on the work we read, so the primary skill I developed in this class was reading a significant quantity of complicated philosophical text and forming a substantial response fairly quickly. response_text: Rueben did a really good job of (not) letting the discussion leads lead the discussion. Haha, just kidding, I just wanted to take a jab at Rueben. I liked the laid-back style of the course and thought the dynamic between Jenn and Rueben worked really well.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I've always thought that philosophy courses should be discussion based.  That there should be limited exposition or lecturing from profs and students should lead the discussion.  Profs Jhun and Stern did an excellent job giving students the ability to lead this course while providing clarifications ad counterbalancing opinions where necessary.  I wouldn't change much.The weekly assignments are painful (providing an attempt at a strong argument often is), but I find them to be incredibly useful tools for my development as a writer/philosopher.  It is the process of writing, being forced to find and form an argument about each reading, rather than the product or even the comments from profs, that is the most useful in this regard.One thing I might consider is allowing 1 skipped writing per semester.  It gives students the ability to be flexible when schedules require (or to just take a break for a week).

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Reuben and Jenn were great at facilitating the discussions during weeks where there was so much material to cover that we could easily have spent the whole class discussing a point that was only tangential to the author's main focus, and guiding us towards productive ways to answer the questions that we as a class disagreed about. The writing components were very helpful for getting us to develop the skill of reading a lot and responding substantially fairly quickly, but given that these were done before any class discussions made them sometimes feel a bit pointless as a way to help us /understand/ the readings better (e.g. there was at least one week where I wrote a response and we spent the whole class talking about things that essentially nullified my response by answering lower-level questions that I had incorrectly assumed answers to).

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I appreciated not having a final paper to worry about. Mostly because I have no effing clue what I would have written about. But it put me more at ease with a syllabus full of material I was largely entirely unfamiliar with and allowed me to just focus on trying to gain as adequate a familiarity with these works as I could without having a paper that would be awful for you to read hanging over me.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The course was very stimulating because of the fact that almost all of the material was new to me, even if I had read other pieces by the same authors before, and our weekly discussions often helped illuminate areas of confusion (that I sometimes did not even realize I was confused about). I think possibly breaking up the weekly writing into two 4-500 word assignments, one written before class discussion and the other written after, could have helped me on an individual level to reflect upon how my understanding of each piece changed from the discussion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Wow. Learned a lot. We started with a pretty fundamental overview of the history behind the philosophy of mind. We started with Descartes, the father of modern philosophy, and moved on from there. Our book, Minds and Computers, concluded with computational theory of mind, which argues that if humans are machines, the brain is basically the hardware and the mind is the software. However, Searle showed us that computationalism can't answer intentionality (formal programs can't constitute understanding), so we have tried to find other theories that may work to explain the mind. Between Heidegger, Wittgenstein, Brentano, Dennet, Hagel, we have come to realize the importance of subjective experience in the world. So far, I really like the embodied mind theory and its appeal to naturalism.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Collaboration, deep thinking, decoding hard and dense texts

response_text: I gained lots of analytical philosophical ability. Namely, logic,  exploring multiple philosophical perspectives, and approaching philosophical problems from a lens beyond just philosophy.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We gained an overview of different theories of mind and how they applied to AI, we learned logical argument construction and breaking down, and how to contstruct turing machines and neural networks.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned sooo much in this course. I learned how to think philosophically and how to challenge arguments using very precise language. I learned how AI works, simple things such as Siri or google AI works. I also learned a variety of philosophical theories of mind which were really interesting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about logical thinking, specifically thinking about necessary and sufficient conditions and how arguments followed from one another. I also learned a lot of specific knowledge about the mechanical processes of computers and AI through the work with neural networks and Turing Machines, and general knowledge about many theories of mind and how they related to the possibility of AI consciousness.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our professor was incredibly willing to dive into a topic that we were wondering about, or spend a long time on a specific question we were struggling with. He began the classes by asking what we had questions about in the reading, which was an incredibly effective and helpful way to teach as it allowed us to gain understanding about the very difficult papers that would have been hard to understand otherwise. Also, he was a major proponent of no technology in the classroom, which I initially disliked but eventually came to greatly appreciate as it helped me and the other students in the class stay focused and engaged.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I definitely learned a lot in this course and was able to continue to grow my thinking and the concept of game theory. One specific thing I learned in the course is the importance of writing effectively. This means, less is more, and conveying your point with evidence in the least amount of words is the key to a successful writer. You want what you are saying to be impactful, and making it come across in that manner is important. Another thing I learned is game theory, and how to play different types of games and strategies. Before this class, I had minimal knowledge of game theory, and now can relate the concepts I learned in this class to my microeconomics course as well. Lastly, I think another skill that I learned from this class is correlating these games and strategies into human behavior and understanding how people make their decisions.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I enjoyed thinking about the intersection of economics, politics, and philosophy. I learned that these three branches are interconnected, I learned different views on governance, and I learned to questions beliefs about political structure that I had held before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new way of thinking through issues using an economic lens. As someone who has never taken a course in economics before, this was a novel concept for me. I also learned about the concept of the Prisoner's Dilemma, and most importantly how to apply it in a real-world context. Lastly, I learned about the importance of the combination of Politics, Philosophy, and Economics (PPE) when attacking complex problems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We learned how to compare and contrast different philosophical readings, how to apply economic frameworks to political issues, and we learned about styles of voting and government.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Exploring the intersections between various disciplines (Politics, Economics, Philosophy). Interdisciplinary approach allowed me to explore ideas from a new perspective and use critical thinking skills to make judgements

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the median voter theorem, different forms of justice, and the origins of social contracts

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. How to combine aspects of multiple disciplines 
2. How to quickly find specific information from dense readings 
3. How to write commentaries using description, analysis, and judgement

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I have taken a class with Prof. Salsman before and something that he is really exceptional at is making individual problems/ideas very multi-dimensional. For example, how you can look at one concept and examine 5 different viewpoints. I also really like how this class is broken up into a bunch of smaller units. Makes the ideas easier to process and think about as well as stay on top of.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about game theory, the impact of politics in the economy, and market competition.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: First off, in this course I learned the similarities and differences in ideology of philosophers such as Locke, Hobbes and Rousseau. I also learned about game theory, and which situations in the real world possess those same incentives. Along with that, I learned about the "Pareto optimal" outcome, as well as a Nash equilibrium. Lastly, the course covers what government and market failures are, and how we know when they take place. Overall, I learned how to think more philosophically about economic and political policies as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: New ways of thinking. I enjoyed learning about political philsophers like Hume and Locke. I enjoyed most of the readings and I thought they provided a lot of unique thought, most notably in the realm of human decsion making.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I built on previous knowledge to better understand spatial and theoretical explanations of political economy. I learned how to implement conceptions of justice, marginal markets, and price theories in academic and practical philosophies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new away to approach the world, through a lense of always asking by what standard, and through incorporating a multifaceted approach.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Problems often have multiple lenses that they can be viewed through. Depending on which angle issues are approached through, different solutions can be more obvious than others. Synthesizing these different views is a difficult task that often has no "right" conclusion.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned how to analyze and dissect articles and documents and formulate critiques/responses to them.
I learned about different viewpoints on justice and economics from esteemed thinkers throughout history.
I leaned how to write my own opinions with regards to ideas presented in class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I think this course helped me learn a lot about the beginnings of PPE. Specifically, I learned a lot about the differences between spontaneous order and deliberate design, the spheres that make up our daily lives, the Median Voter Theorem, the state of nature, and the nature of the state. I have learned differing opinions on many of these topics from different authors.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Evaluating political and economic theories through multiple lenses, connecting political theories/phenomena to economic ones, game theory

response_text: Having the copies of the slides available after each section was really helpful and helped to facilitate my learning. This way I could go back and review concepts that I might have missed during class. This access to course materials should be kept for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I would keep the format of posting the lecture slides as that was very helpful. There were also weekly quizzes but I think switching the questions to vary from not only multiple choice would be helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The slideshows were helpful, especially outside of class to review materials

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Although I attended most lectures, I thought it was nice that the lecture wasn't mandatory and that all the weekly slides were posted online before the quiz opened. But, it would have been even more helpful if the PowerPoints were uploaded at the start of the week rather than the end. But I thought Professor Salsman was an engaging lecturer and very friendly and approachable. I also really appreciated how the weekly quizzes were open for multiple days and were open notes. Although there was a time limit, it was never really a problem to finish on time.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: As mentioned, he makes every student feel engaged and he does not teach like he is lecturing us but, as mentioned, leading a discussion. I much prefer this style of teaching and is why I enrolled in another of Professor Salsman's courses.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor made notes available for the class and gave us optional readings to enhance our learning.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: It's a course that really depends on your level of engagement. It's a basic lecture style course that is entirely optional to attend, but I recommend engaging with the material in class and taking advantage of the questions Professor Salsman poses. I was initially frustrated with the rote style of teaching, but became more interested in both the course and the material once I started pushing back on some of Salsman's assumptions. He appreciates the engagement and he is clearly very knowledgeable about political economics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Throughout this course, learning was facilitated by weekly quizzes on the topics covered in class along with the readings. I think this aspect of the class should be continued in future years because it emphasizes the importance of engaging with the readings, and being able to retain the key points from class.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

This combination is not forced either, because the topics in class that we debate absolutely stretch across these three areas. I think the course would be even more intellectually stimulating if the students got to participate a little bit more actively in the debates. question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: To a future student considering this course, I would say definitely take it and preferably in your first two years at Duke. I think it gives you a great foundational understanding of how Economics, Philosophy and Politics are intertwined in society, and based on which of those areas interests you the most, you can take more specific classes in the future targeting that area. It's a course that appeals to a wide range of people, and I would say if you want to become a more critical thinker about how people make decisions in government and just in society in general, take the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In this class we had discussions of very politically controversial topics every week - I think that one main thing I learned from this teaching style was how to apply different frames of thought to the same issue. More specifically, we applied economic, political, and philosophical analysis to each topic that we reviewed during the course. So I learned to integrate different frameworks into one broader idea / topic. I also learned about different philosophies / approaches to life - for example the difference between egoism and altruism and how these two perspectives influence individuals' way of thinking about different phenomenon. Also, I particularly enjoyed when Professor Salsman opened up abvout his personal research and models on the financial economy and his financial crash predicting model - the finance discussion was particularly interesting to me.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The discussion-based classes were very helpful, as it allowed us to guide the conversations towards topics that we found most intriguing and express/questions our positions. I also appreciated that the syllabus was flexible and could be changed to better fit our interests.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think that Professor Salsman does a uniquely good job in opening the floor of discussion to any and all thoughts and opinions - this is the only class I have EVER taken at Duke where I didn't feel I would be shunned and penalized for making certain conservative arguments that other Professor's typically do not accept or give a second thought. I think this made the class WAY more interesting, because it was the first class with a truly open discussion I have ever attended. I think universities and Duke in particular needs to work on not allowing professors to penalize students for their political opinions, and they should ask Salsman how to do this, because he did a fantastic job at moderating and encouraging discussion of diverse perspectives.
